image.altText: A man in a blue suit walks hand in hand with a woman in a wedding dress whose face has been blurred for privacy.

items.synopsis: Police say they have charged a 36-year-old man known to the father found dead in his Gold Coast hinterland home last week.

title.children: Gold Coast police charge man with murder of Tamborine Mountain father

image.altText: a small silver car is being towed away

items.synopsis: A man on a return to prison warrant has been arrested after leading police on a major search across the city.

title.children: Man arrested after alleged attempted armed carjacking in Townsville

image.altText: A dog with his tongue hanging out, lying on a lawn.

items.synopsis: A Gold Coast dad says his sons are beside themselves as a result of the the "disgusting" crime. The family's car was also stolen and their house was trashed.

title.children: Heartless thieves steal blind dog, shove baby photos into toilet during daylight robbery

image.altText: A woman wearing a camel jacket and black top leans on a fence surrounded by white roses.

items.synopsis: Jacqueline Bradley has worked all her life but found herself unemployed at 61. She's applied for dozens of suitable jobs but says the constant rejection makes it difficult to keep going.

title.children: At 61, Jacqueline can't find work. She doesn't eat until midday

image.altText: Locals hold signs to protest the redevelopment of the Gabba

items.synopsis: Thousands of signatures have been collected to save a local school and park. Residents even fear their homes could be moved to make way for the new-look Gabba.

title.children: Locals losing sleep over fears the Gabba's Olympics rebuild will see their homes bulldozed

image.altText: An elderly man addresses a press conference

items.synopsis: With a primary vote so high it made other politicians envious, Toowoomba Mayor Paul Antonio brushed off competitors election after election. But now, he's calling it quits.

title.children: One of Queensland's 'most popular' politicians calls it quits

image.altText: A woman wearing a black and green jumper and glasses with her young daughter peering over her right shoulder by a window.

items.synopsis: Data from CoreLogic shows rental prices have continued to climb as the market battles chronic housing shortages and rising demand for housing. But despite an increase in the rental vacancy rate, rents are expected to keep rising.

title.children: 'I don't go to the doctor anymore': Angela rents in the most affordable capital city, but one more increase will make her homeless

image.altText: a generic image of a child standing by a window holding a doll. the light is shadowy and their identity isn't clear

items.synopsis: Residential care is considered the last resort for housing children, after kinship and foster care, and especially unsuitable for infants, but an increasing number are living there.

title.children: Queensland Children's Commissioner 'incredibly concerned' by rising number of infants in residential care

image.altText: A PHEV on display at a Shanghai auto exhibition in 2023

items.synopsis: The latest sales figures suggest the age of the plug-in hybrid electric vehicle that can charge from a power point and fill up at the service station appears to be drawing to an end, at least in Australia.

title.children: Plug-in hybrids are being left in the dust as battery EV sales surge ahead

image.altText: Two women looking at a model pink brain

items.synopsis: Sunshine Coast researchers hope a study of adolescents' developing brains will lead to better access to scans as a preventative screening tool for mental health disorders.

title.children: Could 'brain fingerprinting' teens help detect mental health issues earlier?

image.altText: A soldier in protective camouflage gear ducks and holds his helmet as a mortar explodes into the sky behind him

items.synopsis: The counteroffensive is making steady gains, but Ukraine isn't taking any chances. While soldiers grind on in bloody battle, everyday civilians are preparing to defend their villages from a potential Russian advance.

title.children: While Putin was mired in personal drama, Ukraine was quietly carrying out its counteroffensive

image.altText: The windscreen and driver's side of a white van, parked at an angle.

items.synopsis: Energy Safe Victoria warns about the dangers of gas appliances in small spaces after the woman was found dead inside an unventilated campervan with a gas-powered fridge operating beside her in Cohuna last year.

title.children: Coroner confirms 88yo woman died from carbon monoxide poisoning in campervan

image.altText: Paul Smith in his 20s on a motorbike

items.synopsis: Lightning strikes in a split second. Those who survive being struck can be left with lifelong consequences, including cognitive disability, relationship breakdowns and a dark shadow over their mental health.

title.children: Paul was struck by lightning in his 20s. He was never the same again

image.altText: An aerial  shot of a black hearse surrounded by more than a dozen WA Police motorbikes on a road in Perth.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says the nation will mourn with the family and friends of WA Police Constable Anthony Woods, who was killed in the line of duty.

title.children: 'Cruelly robbed of his future': Prime minister pays tribute to fallen officer as funeral gets underway

image.altText: A family poses for a photograph.

items.synopsis: Australia sees skilled migrants as a critical part to filling a jobs shortage but those already here are telling friends not to follow.

title.children: Skilled migrants say 50-year parent visa delays make Australia less attractive

image.altText: Dust rising off a mine site with green hills in the foreground and background.

items.synopsis: Cadia Valley Operations says the NSW mine has breached clean air rules but maintains public health is not at risk.

title.children: Australia's largest gold mine admits to dust pollution as neighbours fear health impacts

image.altText: A protester is challenged by security on tennis court.

items.synopsis: Australia's Daria Saville sees her Wimbledon first-round match interrupted by protesters who invade Court 18 before being arrested by London police, with the UK home secretary promising harsh punishments.

title.children: Dark day for Australians as climate protesters arrested at Wimbledon

image.altText: Stuart Robert sitting in his office, wearing a dark blue suit and blue tie.

items.synopsis: The Liberal Party's candidate in the upcoming Fadden by-election says he hasn't spoken to former minister Stuart Robert in weeks — and he's happy that's the case.

title.children: Liberal candidate hasn't spoken to Stuart Robert in weeks, welcomes 'clear air'

image.altText: A Chinese woman with long hair smiling and gesturing in geometric black and silver dress on red carpet.

items.synopsis: The Hong Kong-born star had been suffering from depression for several years, her sisters said, with her condition deteriorating drastically over the last few months.

title.children: Pop singer CoCo Lee, who voiced Disney's Mulan, dies at 48

image.altText: A man with grey hair standing under a tree

items.synopsis: "Yes" advocates are concerned misinformation on the Voice to Parliament will see a repeat of the 1967 referendum where Kalgoorlie recorded Australia's highest "no" vote.

title.children: WA recorded more 'no' votes than anywhere else in 1967 referendum, could 'myths' on the Voice see it happen again?

image.altText: The crowd cheers on a hill by the side of the road as an Australian cyclist raises his arms riding over the line to win a stage.

items.synopsis: Jai Hindley did his homework ahead of the Tour de France, and it pays off with an opportunistic breakaway on day one in the Pyrenees — now the Perth rider is living his cycling dream with his parents there to witness it, writes Sophie Smith.

title.children: 'Living like a monk' pays off for Aussie Jai Hindley, as his perfect Tour prep is capped by mountain breakaway

image.altText: Close up of Allison Mack walking down the street looking down, surrounded by people

items.synopsis: Allison Mack was sentenced to three years in prison in 2021 after pleading guilty to charges on manipulating women into becoming sex slaves for Keith Raniere, the leader of cult-like group NXIVM.

title.children: Smallville actor released from prison for role in sex-trafficking case tied to cult-like group

image.altText: Fans take their seat at the SCG amid overcast conditions

items.synopsis: Fresh criticism has surfaced about major Australian stadiums' use of facial recognition for ticket-holders to some of the country's biggest events.

title.children: How a trip to the footy could end up with you being 'treated like a criminal'

image.altText: AFL logo

items.synopsis: The AFL is investigating the illegal distribution of explicit images of AFL players that have been shared online without their consent.

title.children: 'Appalling and disgusting act': AFLPA hits out at distribution of explicit player images

image.altText: a wide shot of the brisbane cbd at night with fireworks exploding over the river

items.synopsis: From a warehouse-sized production set to the beloved Riverfire fireworks display, the 2023 Brisbane Festival has promised something for everyone — including hundreds of free events.

title.children: Brisbane Festival's biggest ever event to transform entire warehouse

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading lower, defying gains on all three Wall Street indices overnight, while the Federal Reserve says interest rates will remain higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: ASX slides as Magellan Financial and miners tumble, Federal Reserve says high interest rates here to stay

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And to add a little more to the PwC scandal... Guardian Australia is reporting that a former KPMG partner is urging the federal government to consider a royal commission into the consulting industry. Professor Brendan Lyon, in a submission to a current senate inquiry into the consulting industry, says self-regulation has clearly for the industry. "Unaddressed CEO-level ethics scandals in PwC and KPMG combined with a sustained decline in audit quality by the major accounting firms suggests that professional standards are falling, because self-regulation is failing," he says in his submission. "Australia is unusual in our continuing reliance on self-regulation of the accounting profession. "Accounting scandals have seen most other peer economies implement public oversight and enforcement of professional and ethical standards to better enforce the boundary between profits and principles." Professor Lyon has made three recommendations in his submission ( it is submission #45 ): Recommendation one: The inquiry should recommend the Commonwealth form an independent public regulator styled on the US PCAOB and other international examples, which should: a. Be governed by a board with a majority of independent directors who are prominent professionals in other fields (e.g., doctors, lawyers, company directors), but not accountants. b. Have a statutory investigation function with power to compel information from accounting bodies, firms and individual accountants. c. Have a statutory ethics tribunal function to determine facts and remedies for breaches of APESB and other standards. d. Have a statutory reporting function with obligations on professional bodies to report misconduct, malpractice and other breaches. e. Require statutory registration of large accounting practices and key management personnel thereof. f. Have a research and policy function to engage with the APESB and international standards and ethics bodies, including on enforcement trends. g. Ensure transparent public release of information. Recommendation two: The Commonwealth should consider the utility of a Royal Commission into the accounting profession and major accounting firms, considering: a. The role, function, obligations and expectations on the accounting profession and major firms. b. The cause and remedy to the decline in audit quality by the major accounting firms. c. The cause and remedy to ethics scandals relating to non-assurance consulting work by the major firms. d. Whether there are unreported risks from incomplete corporate and/or public sector financial reporting arising from lax enforcement of professional and ethical standards. e. The adequacy of self-regulation by CAANZ other professional accounting bodies. f. Identify statutory, regulatory and governance reforms to better maintain professional ethics and standards for accountants. My final recommendation concerns the Commonwealth’s interest as a purchaser of services in a consulting market dominated by Big Four accounting firms: Recommendation three : In respect of its own procurement and management of consultants, the Commonwealth should: a. Request the ANAO undertake a detailed performance audit on the selection and management of consultants, including integrity risks to officials and instances of poor professional practice or integrity breaches by consultants. b. Adopt a consultant rotation mechanism, requiring Big Four firms and other ‘top 10’ consultants to sit out one complete year in each four in working for any one department, to avoid entrenched dependence. c. Ban Big Four and other large providers from making political donations. d. Implement similar restrictions and obligations on public sector consultants to those binding public servants under the APS and other codes of conduct. e. Require an annual Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report to the Parliament transparently identifying the value and tendering approach for all engagements larger than $150,000; and identifying any untendered or other non-standard procurements. f. Implement a default five-year ban on Big Four accounting firms found in serious breach of professional ethics by the new Commonwealth regulator, a professional body or statutory entities at a Commonwealth or state level. g. Implement a matching code of ethics in contracts for all other consultants to government, including a corresponding default five-year ban for ethical or professional breaches.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A royal commission into the consulting industry

children.content: And to add a little more to the PwC scandal...
Guardian Australia
is reporting
that a former KPMG partner is urging the federal government to consider a
royal commission
into the consulting industry
Professor Brendan Lyon
, in a submission to a
current senate inquiry
into the consulting industry, says self-regulation has clearly for the industry.
"Unaddressed

CEO-level ethics scandals in PwC and KPMG combined with a sustained decline in audit quality by the major accounting firms suggests that professional standards are falling, because self-regulation is failing," he says in his submission.
"Australia is unusual in our continuing reliance on self-regulation of the accounting profession.

"Accounting scandals have seen most other peer economies implement public oversight and enforcement of professional and ethical standards to better enforce the boundary between profits and principles."
Professor Lyon has made three recommendations in his submission (
it is submission #45
Recommendation one:
The inquiry should recommend the Commonwealth form an independent public regulator styled on the US PCAOB and other international examples, which should:
a. Be governed by a board with a majority of independent directors who are prominent professionals in other fields (e.g., doctors, lawyers, company directors), but not accountants.
b. Have a statutory investigation function with power to compel information from accounting bodies, firms and individual accountants.
c. Have a statutory ethics tribunal function to determine facts and remedies for breaches of APESB and other standards.
d. Have a statutory reporting function with obligations on professional bodies to report misconduct, malpractice and other breaches.
e. Require statutory registration of large accounting practices and key management personnel thereof.
f. Have a research and policy function to engage with the APESB and international standards and ethics bodies, including on enforcement trends. g. Ensure transparent public release of information.
Recommendation two:
The Commonwealth should consider the utility of a Royal Commission into the accounting profession and major accounting firms, considering:
a. The role, function, obligations and expectations on the accounting profession and major firms.
b. The cause and remedy to the decline in audit quality by the major accounting firms.
c. The cause and remedy to ethics scandals relating to non-assurance consulting work by the major firms.
d. Whether there are unreported risks from incomplete corporate and/or public sector financial reporting arising from lax enforcement of professional and ethical standards.
e. The adequacy of self-regulation by CAANZ other professional accounting bodies.
f. Identify statutory, regulatory and governance reforms to better maintain professional ethics and standards for accountants.
My final recommendation concerns the Commonwealth’s interest as a purchaser of services in a consulting market dominated by Big Four accounting firms:
Recommendation three
In respect of its own procurement and management of consultants, the Commonwealth should:

a. Request the ANAO undertake a detailed performance audit on the selection and management of consultants, including integrity risks to officials and instances of poor professional practice or integrity breaches by consultants.

b. Adopt a consultant rotation mechanism, requiring Big Four firms and other ‘top 10’ consultants to sit out one complete year in each four in working for any one department, to avoid entrenched dependence.
c. Ban Big Four and other large providers from making political donations.
d. Implement similar restrictions and obligations on public sector consultants to those binding public servants under the APS and other codes of conduct.

e. Require an annual Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report to the Parliament transparently identifying the value and tendering approach for all engagements larger than $150,000; and identifying any untendered or other non-standard procurements.

f. Implement a default five-year ban on Big Four accounting firms found in serious breach of professional ethics by the new Commonwealth regulator, a professional body or statutory entities at a Commonwealth or state level.
g. Implement a matching code of ethics in contracts for all other consultants to government, including a corresponding default five-year ban for ethical or professional breaches.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Our key index, the ASX 200, tracks the value of the 200-largest listed companies on the stock exchange. Investors have started the day with the 'thumb down' emoji. The benchmark index is down -67.7 points or -0.93% to 7,187.20 points. Here's the top and bottom movers. Payments/buy-now-pay-later digital money conglomerate Block Inc (which ate AfterPay) is up 5% in early trade. Troubled fund manager Magellan Financial Group is down 5.7%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens down

children.content: Our key index, the ASX 200, tracks the value of the 200-largest listed companies on the stock exchange.
Investors have started the day with the 'thumb down' emoji.
The benchmark index is down
-67.7 points or -0.93% to 7,187.20 points.
Here's the top and bottom movers.
Payments/buy-now-pay-later digital money conglomerate
Block Inc
(which ate AfterPay) is up 5% in early trade.
Troubled fund manager
Magellan Financial Group
is down 5.7%

image.altText: Woman sits on a chair in her home

items.synopsis: A Brisbane mum is suing the Queensland government after she allegedly suffered extreme physical and sexual abuse as a child in the state's foster care system.

title.children: Penelope says she was forced to live in a foster home with a boy who had allegedly raped her. She's now suing the state government

image.altText: The premier in a hard hat and fluro vest looking down at papers with a wind turbine in the background.

items.synopsis: Over the next decade, renewable projects in Queensland are set to generate enough new energy to power about 6.6 million homes. But what does this mean for the communities that will host this infrastructure?

title.children: New support available to landholders as Queensland wind and solar continue exponential growth

image.altText: A group of excited English women cricketers high-five and celebrate as a dejected Australian batter stands in the background.

items.synopsis: Australia's women are beaten in a cricket international for the first time since September 2021, as England keep the Women's Ashes alive with a narrow T20I win at The Oval.

title.children: Women's Ashes series alive as England ends Australian winning streak in T20I at The Oval

image.altText: A young blonde woman smiles while sitting on the beach at sunset.

items.synopsis: A committal hearing in Townsville has heard two drivers were allegedly encouraging each other to go "faster and faster" in the lead-up to the 2021 death of aspiring police officer Jennifer Board.

title.children: 'Insane, unsafe, stupid game' was playing out at 180kph before crash that killed 22-year-old, court hears
